explanation:
Agent A is correct. Under certain preprocessing configurations the statement (void)0 is the only statement executed in that if-block and it has no effect on program behaviour, so it meets the definition of dead code in MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.2.

Concretely: if HAVE_MESSAGES is not defined and MSG_NOSIGNAL is defined, the preprocessor yields an if (! sk_spipe_supprs) { (void)0; } body — the (void)0 expression statement is executed when the condition is true but does nothing, and removing it would not change program behaviour. The comment “Mute compiler warning” indicates it exists solely to suppress a warning, which does not change program semantics. Therefore the report that this constitutes a Rule 2.2 violation is correct.

(As remediation, restructure the preprocessor conditionals so the if-body is never reduced to an empty no-op statement — e.g. move the MSG_NOSIGNAL block so there is always meaningful code in the body, or avoid generating an empty block — or document and justify a formal deviation if the suppression is necessary.)
